awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Chemistry at the University of Connecticut
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Connecticut is located in Storrs, CT. The principal investigators are Jose Gascon and Alfredo Angeles-Boza. The site supports the training of 9 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. This site, supported by the Division of Chemistry in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate, provides students with a diverse set of research projects in chemical sciences. Students also take part in in technical workshops and professional development seminars, which emphasize the development of communication skills and ethical behavior in research settings. This program culminates in oral and poster presentations, which is open to the University community, parents and faculty from the students' home institutions. Participants obtain a foundation for making informed choices about future careers in chemistry and establish networks with peers from a range of disciplines and experiences. In the recruitment of students, an emphasis is placed on women, underrepresented groups and students from the nearby Central Connecticut State University (CCSU). 

This program introduces participants to a full breadth of research-related activities, a number of ancillary technical workshops and professional development seminars. The research projects span across all divisions of the University of Connecticut's chemistry department, including projects related to organic, inorganic, analytical, physical, biological, and polymer chemistry. In addition to the research conducted in the host laboratories, students participate in two hands-on workshops: one on computational chemistry and the other on single crystal X-ray crystallography held at CCSU. These activities introduce an intellectually challenging technical component to the program that involves the entire cohort and provides a deeper understanding about techniques that are instrumental to all fields of chemistry. Overall, the program enhances students' enthusiasm for chemistry and prepares them for post-graduate success in the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Chemistry REU Program at the University of Connecticut succeeded in providing an intensive research experience for 34 undergraduate students over the grant funding cycle. Students were matched with research mentors across chemistry disciplines and gained hands-on training in state-of-the-art laboratories. Besides lab work, students participated in professional development activities like ethics and safety training, as well as graduate school advising. They presented their research findings through talks and posters.

The program demonstrates intellectual merit through the advancements made to chemistry knowledge. The research conducted resulted in 7 peer-reviewed publications and 1 conference poster that add to scientific understanding. Students tackled questions relevant to their research groups and made contributions. The program also provided new educational materials, like a Quantum Chemistry workshop, that can be used in future REU programs and undergraduate courses.

This program has broader impacts by increasing diversity in chemistry research. It targeted students from institutions with limited research capabilities, exposing them to graduate-level work. The goal of encouraging these students to pursue chemistry careers was met, with most participants continuing to graduate studies in the field. More broadly, the 34 students gaining research skills and experience contributes to a stronger chemistry workforce pipeline. Overall, this REU Program achieved meaningful outcomes across training the next generation of chemists, advancing chemistry research, and disseminating findings.
